com.beaglebuddy.mp3

Class MP3Base

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.beaglebuddy.mp3.MP3BaseID3v23
      • com.beaglebuddy.mp3.MP3BaseID3v24
        • com.beaglebuddy.mp3.MP3Base
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    MP3

    public class MP3Base
extends MP3BaseID3v24

    This base class provides some underlying methods that help make the derived MP3 class's interface much cleaner and easier to understand. Thus, this class provides lower level methods that are used by the MP3 class, but would otherwise clutter the MP3 class's public interface.

      • MP3Base

        protected MP3Base(java.io.InputStream inputStream)
           throws java.io.IOException
        This constructor reads the ID3 tag(s), which contain the information about the song, from the .mp3 file pointed to by the specified input stream. This constructor is usefull for reading .mp3 files from a compressed source (.zip file), from a 3rd party streaming source, etc.
        Parameters:
        inputStream - An input stream pointing to an .mp3 file.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there is a problem reading the contents of the .mp3 file from the input stream.

      • validateMPEGFrames

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> validateMPEGFrames()
                                                    throws java.io.IOException
        This method reads through the audio portion of an .mp3 file and validates the MPEG audio frames. It makes sure that the MPEG audio frames:

        • are the correct type: MPEG 1 Layer |||
        • are located where they are supposed to be
        • have valid MPEG frame headers
        • have a valid structure (frame header followed by side information followed by audio data)
        • use the same bit rate for every audio sample when the mp3 file is encoded with a constant bit rate

        It also makes sure that:

        • Xing, Lame, and VBRI headers occur only in the 1st MPEG audio frame
        • VBR encoded .mp3 files contain a VBR header

        note:
        This method should only be called on .mp3 files that are loaded from a file system. This is due to the amount of time it takes to download and read through an .mp3 file that is loaded from a URL. If invoked on an .mp3 loaded from a URL, this method will simply return an empty list, indicating no errors were found.
        Returns:
        a list of errors found in the MPEG audio section of the .mp3 file. If no errors were found, then an empty list is returned.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the .mp3 file can not be read.
        See Also:
        ID3v1 specification, APE v2 specification, LYRICS 3.2 specification

      • hasErrors

        public boolean hasErrors()
        determines if the mp3 file had any errors in the information stored in the frames of the ID3v2.x tag. If any of the ID3v2.x frames were invalid, then they are removed from the ID3v2.x tag.
        Returns:
        whether any invalid ID3v2.x frames were found in the ID3v2.x tag from the .mp3 file.
        See Also:
        getErrors(), displayErrors(PrintStream)

      • getErrors

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getErrors()
        gets a list of any errors found in the ID3v2.x tag.
        Returns:
        a list of errors found in the ID3v2.x tag. If no errors were found, then an empty list is returned.
        See Also:
        hasErrors(), displayErrors(PrintStream)

      • displayErrors

        public void displayErrors(java.io.PrintStream printStream)
        displays any errors found in the ID3v2.x tag from the .mp3 file. If no errors were found, then nothing is written to the print stream.
        Parameters:
        printStream - print stream used to write out the errors.
        See Also:
        getErrors(), hasErrors()

      • getPath

        public java.lang.String getPath()
        gets the path to the .mp3 file. This method may be called regardless of whether the .mp3 file was loaded from a file system, an input stream, or from a url.

        Example:
             // load the song "Take Hold of the Flame" from Queensryche's album, "The Warning".
     MP3 mp3 = new MP3("c:/mp3/queensryche/the warning/take hold of the flame.mp3");
     System.out.println("the mp3 file was loaded from " + mp3.getPath());

     // load the song "Take Hold of the Flame" from Queensryche's album, "The Warning".
     MP3 mp3 = new MP3("http://www.beaglebuddy.com/mp3/queensryche/the warning/take hold of the flame.mp3");
     System.out.println("the mp3 file was loaded from " + mp3.getPath());
        Returns:
        the path to the .mp3 file.

      • getFirstMpegFrame

        public MPEGFrame getFirstMpegFrame()
        gets the first MPEGFrame found after the ID3v2.x tag. MP3 files store the audio data in MPEG audio frames. They should occur one right after the other and form an unbroken stream of MPEG audio frames. Almost all of the mp3 programs and libraries available on the internet today find the first MPEG audio frame by searching the .mp3 file following the ID3v2.x tag which is located at the beginning of the .mp3 file. While this works most of the time, there is a problem with this method. It is possible that a "false synch" is encountered. That is, what appears to be a valid MPEG audio frame is really just some other data that just happens to look like an actual MPEG audio frame. For this reason, the Beaglebuddy mp3 library checks to make sure that the first MPEG audio frame found is directly followed by the second MPEG audio frame. If it isn't, then the Beaglebuddy mp3 library continues searching until it finds two valid MPEG audio frames in a row. When two valid MPEG audio frames are found in a row, then we are reasonably certain that the beginning of the MPEG audio stream has indeed been found and not a "false synch". Since the bit rate type, codec, frequency, bit rate, etc. are all obtained from the first MPEG audio frame, you might see discrepancies between the Beaglebuddy mp3 library and other programs. The reason is because the Beaglebuddy mp3 library is more stringent when locating the first MPEG audio frame than are the other .mp3 programs.
        Returns:
        the first mpeg audio frame found after the ID3v2.x tag.

      • getID3v24TagAtEnd

        public ID3v24Tag getID3v24TagAtEnd()
                            throws java.io.IOException,
                                   java.lang.IllegalStateException
        gets the optional ID3v2.4 tag found at the end of an .mp3 file. This really is a stupid addition to the Id3v2.4 standard.
        Returns:
        the ID3v2.4 tag found at the end of an .mp3 file if present. Otherwise null is returned.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there is a problem reading the .mp3 file.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the mp3 song was loaded from a URL and therefore will take a considerable amount of time to reach the ID3v2.4 tag at the end of the .mp3 file.

      • removeID3v1Tag

        public void removeID3v1Tag()
                    throws java.io.IOException
        remove the ID3v1 tag at the end of the .mp3 file. This method simply truncates the end of the .mp3 file to remove the ID3v1 tag, and hence does not require a call to the MP3.save() method. It does not save any changes to the ID3v2.x tag.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there was an error truncating the ID3v1 tag from the end of the .mp3 file.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the mp3 song was loaded from a URL and is therefore considered to be read only and thus may not be modified.

      • removeLyrics3v1Tag

        public void removeLyrics3v1Tag()
                        throws java.io.IOException
        remove the Lyrics3v1 tag at the end of the .mp3 file. This method simply truncates the end of the .mp3 file to remove the Lyrics3v1 tag, and hence does not require a call to the MP3.save() method. It does not save any changes to the ID3v2.x tag. Since the Lyrics3v1 tag is found after the mpeg audio and before the ID3v1 tag at the end of the .mp3 file, removing the Lyrics3v1 tag from the .mp3 file will also remove the ID3v1 tag as well.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there was an error truncating the Lyrics3v1 tag from the end of the .mp3 file.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the mp3 song was loaded from a URL and is therefore considered to be read only and thus may not be modified, or if the mp3 file does not contain a Lyrics3v1 tag.

      • removeLyrics3v2Tag

        public void removeLyrics3v2Tag()
                        throws java.io.IOException
        remove the Lyrics3v2 tag at the end of the .mp3 file. This method simply truncates the end of the .mp3 file to remove the Lyrics3v2 tag, and hence does not require a call to the MP3.save() method. It does not save any changes to the ID3v2.x tag. Since the Lyrics3v2 tag is found after the mpeg audio and before the ID3v1 tag at the end of the .mp3 file, removing the Lyrics3v2 tag from the .mp3 file will also remove the ID3v1 tag as well.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there was an error truncating Lyrics3v2 tag from the end of the .mp3 file.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the mp3 song was loaded from a URL and is therefore considered to be read only and thus may not be modified, or if the mp3 file does not contain a Lyrics3v2 tag.

      • removeAPETag

        public void removeAPETag()
                  throws java.io.IOException
        remove the APE tag at the end of the .mp3 file. This method simply truncates the end of the .mp3 file to remove the APE tag, and hence does not require a call to the MP3.save() method. It does not save any changes to the ID3v2.x tag. Since the APE tag is found after the mpeg audio and before the ID3v1 tag, if present, at the end of the .mp3 file, removing the APE tag from the end of the .mp3 file will also remove the ID3v1 tag, if it is present, as well.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there was an error truncating APE tag from the end of the .mp3 file.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the mp3 song was loaded from a URL and is therefore considered to be read only and thus may not be modified, or if the mp3 file does not contain an APE tag.

      • removeID3v24TagAtEnd

        public void removeID3v24TagAtEnd()
                          throws java.io.IOException
        remove the ID3v2.4 tag at the end of the .mp3 file. If the ID3v2.4 tag is not found at the absolute very end of the .mp3 file, then no action is taken and the .mp3 file is left untouched.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there was an error truncating ID3v2.4 tag from the end of the .mp3 file.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the mp3 song was loaded from a URL and is therefore considered to be read only and thus may not be modified.

      • getID3v2xPadding

        public int getID3v2xPadding()
        gets the size of the padding inside the ID3v2.x tag.
        Returns:
        the size of the padding, in bytes, inside the ID3v2.x tag.
        See Also:
        setID3v2xPadding(int)

      • setID3v2xPadding

        public void setID3v2xPadding(int newPaddingSize)
                      throws java.io.IOException
        this method sets the padding inside the ID3v2.x tag to the specified amount and saves the .mp3 file. If the .mp3 file has an ID3v2.4 tag which itself contains a footer, then the padding will not be set, as padding and the footer are mutually exclusive.
        Parameters:
        newPaddingSize - the new size, in bytes, that the ID3v2.x padding should be set to.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an error occurs while saving the .mp3 file.
        See Also:
        getID3v2xPadding()

      • saveID3v23

        protected void saveID3v23()
                   throws java.io.IOException
        save the ID3v2.3 tag to the .mp3 file. This is a very messy method, and you really have to understand the ID3v2.3 structure to understand this method. So, if you can, by all means, avoid reading the code in this method.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there was an error writing the ID3v2.3 tag to the .mp3 file.

      • saveID3v24

        protected void saveID3v24()
                   throws java.io.IOException
        save the ID3v2.4 tag to the .mp3 file. This is a very messy method, and you really have to understand the ID3v2.4 structure to understand this method. So, if you can, by all means, avoid reading the code in this method.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there was an error writing the ID3v2.4 tag to the .mp3 file.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        gets a string representation of the mp3 file.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        string representation of the mp3 file.
